issue.title: Email Addresses in mailto links are incorrectly escaped
issue.body: When linking to an email address in markdown, link text is displayed correctly but the hyperlink has extra escaping on the `@` character, which breaks the email address. For example: `[test@examples.com](mailto:test@example.com)` becomes `test@example.com` I believe this is being caused by double-escaping somewhere, as `@` is the correct entity for the `@` character.

comment.body: There's a tricky dance that happens with escaping the `@` symbol and Razor parsing. Even though escaping `@` isn't necessary for plain old Markdown, it's so common to run Statiq documents through the Razor processor, that escaping them after Markdown rendering is the default behavior. If you're creating your own pipelines and want to turn off automatic `@` escaping entirely (which is only advisable when _not_ using Razor downstream of the Markdown module), you can call `EscapeAt(false)` on the `RenderMarkdown` module: ``` // ... new RenderMarkdown().EscapeAt(false); // ... ``` Otherwise there's really no way to tell when an `@` symbol in post-Markdown content is intended to be a Razor instruction or was from the Markdown output, so they all get escaped. If you want to disable this behavior for a specific `@` symbol as with a `mailto:` link, you can escape it with `\@`: ``` [test\@examples.com](mailto:test\@example.com) ``` That produces: ``` test@examples.com ``` Which obviously isn't _quite_ right because the `@` symbol in the `a` element is still escaped. That's because of the way the Markdown renderer sequences the generated link element output vs. the content rendering, and where the escaping happens. To get _exactly_ what you want, you can put the mail link HTML right in the Markdown document, with the `\@` escaping: ``` test\@example.com ``` Which produces the desired unescaped output: ``` test@example.com ``` Note that this all appears to be academic. The client should correctly interpret the HTML entities and convert them back to the correct characters: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1020407/206793890-d106ae24-69d9-49fb-82d5-581ecdd5a841.png) Is that not what you're seeing? I.e. in the rendered output does the `mailto:` link with `#64;` entities not work when clicked or display to the user incorrectly?

issue.title: Netlify deployment not deploying dot files/directories
issue.body:
As reported by @patriksvensson if you create a folder like `.well-known` it'll get generated and output as expected, but won't deploy to Netlify. Thanks to @nils-a for finding this Netlify thread that seems to explain and confirm the behavior: https://answers.netlify.com/t/netlify-deploy-api-removes-files-and-directories-beginning-with-a-period/37728

So the questions is how to fix it? We could automatically look for this pattern, move the files, and create redirect entries as suggested in https://github.com/netlify/cli/issues/11#issuecomment-401854074, but that seems _really_ hacky.

Remove type attribute on stylesheet links, as per recommended practice

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/link#attr-type
Move rel attribute after href for consistence
Consistently use double-quoted attribute values unless a double quote is involved
Modify comment because Bootstrap 5 no more depends on jQuery
Add .editorconfig so we can all agree about line endings, indentation, etc.
Fix aesthetic issues (excess spacing, newlines) in .cshtml files

Consistently use double-quoted attribute values unless a double quote is involved

A previous commit only applied to _layout.cshtml; this one is a review
of all .cshtml files.
Use text-bg-* classes because Bootstrap 5 no longer has badge-* classes
Remove styles and scripts that were only needed by the "Contact Me" page
Change classes float-left > float-start, float-right > float-end because Bootstrap 5
Change data attributes because of change in Bootstrap 5
Use IsArchive setting to better tell archive pages from others

Refactor scripts and styles, bringing in upstream changes, plus what follows:

- no more jQuery as it is not needed by Bootstrap 5 and upstream
- remaining scripts refactored to not use jQuery
- _navbar partial contains only <li> items, the <ul> is external
- search box in navbar is now a proper navbar item
- Lunr, pako, search.js only included in search page
- better overridability for styles
- masthead gray overlay only displayed over images, not gradients
- masthead gradient color is now overridable

Most of these changes are interdependent, hence the single commit.

pull_request.title: Update dependencies, refactor styles and scripts, add some goodies
pull_request.body:
Since #15 and #16 are unfortunately out of date, here's an update to current versions.

**EDIT:** I kinda got carried away 😁 so here are more changes:

- Update styles and scripts from [upstream](https://github.com/StartBootstrap/startbootstrap-clean-blog) where they have undergone some serious refactoring.
- Refactor styles to better separate upstream styles from modifications and expand override possibilities (e.g. make customization of Bootstrap variables possible by just adding one input file in a site).
- Remove styles, scripts and dependencies that were only used by the contacts page.
- Refactor what little JavaScript remains to not use jQuery.
- Remove jQuery as neither Bootstrap 5 nor upstream code depends on it any more.
- Add better styling for blockquotes (see #22) ![blockquote](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/139223/197311285-d3cda467-8371-4684-9dc5-8e130abd4131.png)
- Add pluggable comment engines and Giscus support (see #24)
- Add an `IsPage` boolean setting for pages ("About" and the like). Pages should be put in a `pages` folder and are added to the navigation bar by default.
- Set `Order` to 98 for Posts and 99 for Tags, thus establishing a clear rule for navbar links: pages with an `Order` of at least 100 will be linked after archives.
- Rename `_post-footer` partial to `_post-after-content` as it is not actually included in the footer.
- Add a `_page-after-content` partial for consistency with `_post-after-content`.
- Add a `_common-after-content` partial for _all_ pages, included just after `_post-after-content` in posts and just after `_page-after-content` in pages.
- Move the navbar's `<ul>` tag in `_navigation.cshtml`, leaving only the items in `_navbar.cshtml`
- Make the navbar's search field a proper navbar item, so that there's a correct margin between it and the last navbar link.
- Add a `.editorconfig` file to the repository for better collaboration.
- Remove unused images (i.e. the whole `img` folder).
- Remove redundant favicon link.
- Remove unused sidebar styles.
- Make the masthead gradient configurable.
- Add support for an `ImageAttribution` setting. If it is present in any page, a nice semi-transparent badge is created in the lower-right corner of the masthead, with the value of `ImageAttribution` inserted as raw HTML. Makes displaying proper attribution for images very easy, for example when using photos from [Unsplash](https://unsplash.com).
- Make the copyright notice fully customizable, so for example proper CC licensing can be applied without having to override the whole footer.
- Add support for a `SiteDescription` global setting to set the home page subtitle.

comment.body: There's certainly no reason your own consuming application couldn't target .NET 7, even if the Statiq dependencies are targeting .NET 6. Especially if what you're after is better codegen scenarios since those are mostly driven by the compilation process.

comment.body:
I don't want to drag this out any longer than we need to since it's already been on the shelf for a while. @atiq-cs I really appreciate your willingness to do a full review! Is there a middle ground though where you'd be able to just run through a generation with the new theme and see if anything sticks out? I don't know that we have to verify every change, just make sure it's not going to blow up on new users. If we've passed that minimum bar I'm okay merging it in - we can always iterate and/or fix things as they come later.

Thanks both!

Go team! Thanks for the input everyone, glad I surfaced this one to the community.

> In that case I think a separate pr is cleaner.

I agree, and in general I try to stick to the lowest possible target to allow the largest number of consumers. I've been on the consumption end where I'm unable to update my own targeting so I appreciate when projects don't retarget just for retargeting sake.

@colombod let's do this:

By separating the PRs and releases we can also let anyone who needs to stay on .NET Core 3.1 get the workspaces update and then hang out on that release.

Sound good?

issue.title: Compilation hangs when dotnet-sdk-7 is installed
issue.body:
### Description

If I install `dotnet-sdk-7` besides `dotnet-sdk-6`, the compilation hangs after analyzing project file.

I.e. on console output, with version 6 I get full output, but on version 7 the "Started Fable compilation..." never gets printed.
```
...
Project and references (235 source files) parsed in 3443ms

Started Fable compilation...
....
```

Adding `global.json` with sdk version set to `6.0.403` fixes the problem.

### Related information

* Fable version: `3.7.20`
* Operating system:
  * Ubuntu Linux 22.04 (dotnet installed through Ubuntu's official dotnet install channel)
  * Dotnet runtimes `6.0.11` and `7.0.0`

issue.title: Improve image handling
issue.body:
### Motivation

* Prevent repeatedly downloading images in preview mode
* Workaround for #39 

### Checklist

- [X] Code follows coding conventions held in this repo
- [ ] Automated tests have been added
- [ ] Tests are passing
- [ ] Docs have been updated (if applicable)
- [ ] Temporary settings (e.g. variables used during development and testing) have been reverted to defaults

### How to test

If manual testing is required, what are the steps?

comment.body:
I'm here! Well...sort of. You probably know as well as anyone how flaky my available time has been this year.

In any case, I did get a chance to take a look at the stuff here.

> I noticed Statiq is caching some files already, is there a mechanism in Statiq I can hook into as well?

There isn't really a generic file-based caching mechanism. That said, Statiq does try to track the files it writes, and if the input to a module is the same as a previous run, and the file on disk hasn't changed, it can be a little clever. That works mostly for things like Razor and Markdown processing though - it doesn't really work that well for stuff from the web because we have no way of knowing if anything has changed.

That said, you can obviously be a little smarter for this scenario than Statiq can be for a more generic feature, so some disk caching probably makes sense. There's a `ConcurrentCache<TKey, TValue>` class in `Statiq.Common` that might help: https://www.statiq.dev/api/statiq.common/concurrentcache_2/. It attempts to provide a slightly smarter concurrent dictionary you can use for storing cached data and (optionally) resetting in between executions.

One thing you probably do want to do is use `IFileSystem.CachePath` for the path where you're storing any cached files. That will ensure Statiq doesn't overwrite them or anything when it shouldn't and stay consistent with other cached information. The convention would probably be to create a subfolder under the `CachePath` directory for your own cached files. There are also some `IReadOnlyFileSystem` extensions for working with the cache path that can help resolve full file paths to the cache directory at runtime.

Here's a good example of some custom caching in action for the Razor module: https://github.com/statiqdev/Statiq.Framework/blob/1a8bd58e6f1a4e63f0cae2870db78126bc511928/src/extensions/Statiq.Razor/RazorService.cs#L56

> I'm also running into issues with the ReadWeb module from Statiq Framework that is spawning a task for each image

Yeah, that's probably an unfortunate design. It currently uses `ParallelSelectAsync` which is essentially a call to `Task.WhenAll()`, so while the task manager does have an upper task limit and some queuing built in, it's probably nowhere near reasonable for throttling web requests.

I'm getting a little bit of deja vu because I feel like I've tackled this problem a few times already. One approach off the top of my head is at: https://github.com/daveaglick/discoverdotnet/blob/master/FoundationManager.cs - that queues up web requests using a semaphore.

Anything inbox that does a better job of batching/queuing web requests would be a great addition - and I trust you, so I wouldn't need to review it very closely which is an added bonus :)

issue.title: Use of Assembly.Location makes this incompatible with single file EXEs

labels.name: Out Of Scope
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issue.body:
For a project I am working on, I was interested in trying out the [single file EXE](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/deploying/single-file/overview?tabs=cli).  Unfortunately, due to the use of `Assembly.Location` [in at least one spot](https://github.com/daveaglick/Buildalyzer/blob/main/src/Buildalyzer/ProjectAnalyzer.cs#L255) (which is [incompatible with single file EXEs](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/deploying/single-file/overview?tabs=cli#api-incompatibility)) causes the application to hang indefinitely while attempting to build the project out of process.

The output of the [`ProcessRunner`](https://github.com/daveaglick/Buildalyzer/blob/main/src/Buildalyzer/ProjectAnalyzer.cs#L167) shows the logger switch causes the build to fail, and apparently never return:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38168572/190872350-f54c5241-5cf2-4ce8-965f-42eedd7159f5.png)

Of course, the workaround is to _not_ do a single file EXE, but the single file feature is quite nice.

issue.title: How to do a (fast) design-time build?

comment.body:
Buildalyzer works by calling MSBuild from the command line (the same way you can) while passing it a special logger that sends messages over a pipe back to Buildalyzer for analysis. Performing a "real" design-time build is a challenge - Visual Studio and other IDEs set _a lot_ of different MSBuild properties to make that work correctly, and the correct combinations aren't well documented (if at all).

For C# I was able to reverse-engineer the set of properties to use, which Buildalyzer does by setting environment variables before calling MSBuild. However, in F# the code was entirely donated by the community - I know very little about how the F# compiler works and interacts with MSBuild outside of the unit tests in Buildalyzer I use to verify it's at least returning results. My ability to debug Buildalyzer working against an F# project is very limited. If you happen to figure out the correct set of MSBuild properties to configure for a fast design-time build of an F# project, let me know and we can look at updating the MSBuild call with those. The first step would probably be seeing if you can get it to work from a raw MSBuild command-line (I.e. without Buildalyzer at all) by using the MSBuild CLI switch for setting properties - play around with that until you figure out the right super-set of properties, then we can integrate them.

issue.title: Fix Lunr Search Resource Paths
issue.body:
At present, setting the `SearchScriptPath` key does not change the script path as expected, but changes the index path. This patch fixes the `SearchScriptPath` to work as expected, as well as adding keys to set the path for the index and results file.

Note that as this changes the behaviour of the existing `SearchScriptPath` key, this should be considered a breaking change. However, dealing with this is simply a matter of changing `SearchScriptPath` to `SearchIndexPath` in any configuration.

This also addresses a "feature" in Azure Static Apps, where files ending in `.gz` are served with compression headers, causing browsers to automatically decompress the file before passing the result to javascript. This causes the search script to fail, as it is expecting compressed data.

comment.body: Thanks again!

pull_request.title: Fix Lunr Search Resource Paths
pull_request.body:
At present, setting the `SearchScriptPath` key does not change the script path as expected, but changes the index path. This patch fixes the `SearchScriptPath` to work as expected, as well as adding keys to set the path for the index and results file.

Note that as this changes the behaviour of the existing `SearchScriptPath` key, this should be considered a breaking change. However, dealing with this is simply a matter of changing `SearchScriptPath` to `SearchIndexPath` in any configuration.

This also addresses a "feature" in Azure Static Apps, where files ending in `.gz` are served with compression headers, causing browsers to automatically decompress the file before passing the result to javascript. This causes the search script to fail, as it is expecting compressed data.

issue.title: Fix Lunr Search Resource Paths
issue.body:
At present, setting the `SearchScriptPath` key does not change the script path as expected, but changes the index path. This patch fixes the `SearchScriptPath` to work as expected, as well as adding keys to set the path for the index and results file.

Note that as this changes the behaviour of the existing `SearchScriptPath` key, this should be considered a breaking change. However, dealing with this is simply a matter of changing `SearchScriptPath` to `SearchIndexPath` in any configuration.

This also addresses a "feature" in Azure Static Apps, where files ending in `.gz` are served with compression headers, causing browsers to automatically decompress the file before passing the result to javascript. This causes the search script to fail, as it is expecting compressed data.

- Add pluggable comment engines and Giscus support (see #24)
- Add an `IsArchive` boolean setting to archive pages (index, posts, tags) and use it to tell them apart from other pages instead of comparing page titles - this also fixes the unwanted presence of a comment section in posts/index.html
- Move the navbar's `<ul>` tag in `_navigation.cshtml`, leaving only the items in `_navbar.cshtml`

issue.title: Email Addresses in mailto links are incorrectly escaped
issue.body: When linking to an email address in markdown, link text is displayed correctly but the hyperlink has extra escaping on the `@` character, which breaks the email address. For example: `[test@examples.com](mailto:test@example.com)` becomes `test@example.com` I believe this is being caused by double-escaping somewhere, as `@` is the correct entity for the `@` character.

comment.body: There's a tricky dance that happens with escaping the `@` symbol and Razor parsing. Even though escaping `@` isn't necessary for plain old Markdown, it's so common to run Statiq documents through the Razor processor, that escaping them after Markdown rendering is the default behavior. If you're creating your own pipelines and want to turn off automatic `@` escaping entirely (which is only advisable when _not_ using Razor downstream of the Markdown module), you can call `EscapeAt(false)` on the `RenderMarkdown` module: ``` // ... new RenderMarkdown().EscapeAt(false); // ... ``` Otherwise there's really no way to tell when an `@` symbol in post-Markdown content is intended to be a Razor instruction or was from the Markdown output, so they all get escaped. If you want to disable this behavior for a specific `@` symbol as with a `mailto:` link, you can escape it with `\@`: ``` [test\@examples.com](mailto:test\@example.com) ``` That produces: ``` test@examples.com ``` Which obviously isn't _quite_ right because the `@` symbol in the `a` element is still escaped. That's because of the way the Markdown renderer sequences the generated link element output vs. the content rendering, and where the escaping happens. To get _exactly_ what you want, you can put the mail link HTML right in the Markdown document, with the `\@` escaping: ``` test\@example.com ``` Which produces the desired unescaped output: ``` test@example.com ``` Note that this all appears to be academic. The client should correctly interpret the HTML entities and convert them back to the correct characters: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1020407/206793890-d106ae24-69d9-49fb-82d5-581ecdd5a841.png) Is that not what you're seeing? I.e. in the rendered output does the `mailto:` link with `#64;` entities not work when clicked or display to the user incorrectly?

issue.title: Netlify deployment not deploying dot files/directories
issue.body:
As reported by @patriksvensson if you create a folder like `.well-known` it'll get generated and output as expected, but won't deploy to Netlify. Thanks to @nils-a for finding this Netlify thread that seems to explain and confirm the behavior: https://answers.netlify.com/t/netlify-deploy-api-removes-files-and-directories-beginning-with-a-period/37728

So the questions is how to fix it? We could automatically look for this pattern, move the files, and create redirect entries as suggested in https://github.com/netlify/cli/issues/11#issuecomment-401854074, but that seems _really_ hacky.

pull_request.title: Update dependencies, refactor styles and scripts, add some goodies
pull_request.body:
Since #15 and #16 are unfortunately out of date, here's an update to current versions.

**EDIT:** I kinda got carried away 😁 so here are more changes:

- Update styles and scripts from [upstream](https://github.com/StartBootstrap/startbootstrap-clean-blog) where they have undergone some serious refactoring.
- Refactor styles to better separate upstream styles from modifications and expand override possibilities (e.g. make customization of Bootstrap variables possible by just adding one input file in a site).
- Remove styles, scripts and dependencies that were only used by the contacts page.
- Refactor what little JavaScript remains to not use jQuery.
- Remove jQuery as neither Bootstrap 5 nor upstream code depends on it any more.
- Add better styling for blockquotes (see #22) ![blockquote](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/139223/197311285-d3cda467-8371-4684-9dc5-8e130abd4131.png)
- Add pluggable comment engines and Giscus support (see #24)
- Add an `IsPage` boolean setting for pages ("About" and the like). Pages should be put in a `pages` folder and are added to the navigation bar by default.
- Set `Order` to 98 for Posts and 99 for Tags, thus establishing a clear rule for navbar links: pages with an `Order` of at least 100 will be linked after archives.
- Rename `_post-footer` partial to `_post-after-content` as it is not actually included in the footer.
- Add a `_page-after-content` partial for consistency with `_post-after-content`.
- Add a `_common-after-content` partial for _all_ pages, included just after `_post-after-content` in posts and just after `_page-after-content` in pages.
- Move the navbar's `<ul>` tag in `_navigation.cshtml`, leaving only the items in `_navbar.cshtml`
- Make the navbar's search field a proper navbar item, so that there's a correct margin between it and the last navbar link.
- Add a `.editorconfig` file to the repository for better collaboration.
- Remove unused images (i.e. the whole `img` folder).
- Remove redundant favicon link.
- Remove unused sidebar styles.
- Make the masthead gradient configurable.
- Add support for an `ImageAttribution` setting. If it is present in any page, a nice semi-transparent badge is created in the lower-right corner of the masthead, with the value of `ImageAttribution` inserted as raw HTML. Makes displaying proper attribution for images very easy, for example when using photos from [Unsplash](https://unsplash.com).
- Make the copyright notice fully customizable, so for example proper CC licensing can be applied without having to override the whole footer.
- Add support for a `SiteDescription` global setting to set the home page subtitle.

- Rename `_post-footer` partial to `_post-after-content` as it is not actually included in the footer.
- Add a `_page-after-content` partial for consistency with `_post-after-content`.
- Add a `_common-after-content` partial for _all_ pages, included just after `_post-after-content` in posts and just after `_page-after-content` in pages.
- Move the navbar's `<ul>` tag in `_navigation.cshtml`, leaving only the items in `_navbar.cshtml`
- Make the navbar's search field a proper navbar item, so that there's a correct margin between it and the last navbar link.
- Add a `.editorconfig` file to the repository for better collaboration.
- Remove unused images (i.e. the whole `img` folder).
- Remove redundant favicon link.
- Remove unused sidebar styles.
- Make the masthead gradient configurable.
- Add support for an `ImageAttribution` setting. If it is present in any page, a nice semi-transparent badge is created in the lower-right corner of the masthead, with the value of `ImageAttribution` inserted as raw HTML. Makes displaying proper attribution for images very easy, for example when using photos from [Unsplash](https://unsplash.com).
- Make the copyright notice fully customizable, so for example proper CC licensing can be applied without having to override the whole footer.
- Add support for a `SiteDescription` global setting to set the home page subtitle.

---

Oh, by the way - closes #25

comment.body:
I don't want to drag this out any longer than we need to since it's already been on the shelf for a while. @atiq-cs I really appreciate your willingness to do a full review! Is there a middle ground though where you'd be able to just run through a generation with the new theme and see if anything sticks out? I don't know that we have to verify every change, just make sure it's not going to blow up on new users. If we've passed that minimum bar I'm okay merging it in - we can always iterate and/or fix things as they come later.

Thanks both!

- Add a `.editorconfig` file to the repository for better collaboration.
- Remove unused images (i.e. the whole `img` folder).

If it is present in any page, a nice semi-transparent badge is created in the lower-right corner of the masthead, with the value of `ImageAttribution` inserted as raw HTML. issue.title: Improve image handling
issue.body:
### Motivation

* Prevent repeatedly downloading images in preview mode
* Workaround for #39 

### Checklist

- [X] Code follows coding conventions held in this repo
- [ ] Automated tests have been added
- [ ] Tests are passing
- [ ] Docs have been updated (if applicable)
- [ ] Temporary settings (e.g. variables used during development and testing) have been reverted to defaults

### How to test

If manual testing is required, what are the steps?

comment.body:
I'm here! Well...sort of. You probably know as well as anyone how flaky my available time has been this year.

In any case, I did get a chance to take a look at the stuff here.

> I noticed Statiq is caching some files already, is there a mechanism in Statiq I can hook into as well?

There isn't really a generic file-based caching mechanism. That said, Statiq does try to track the files it writes, and if the input to a module is the same as a previous run, and the file on disk hasn't changed, it can be a little clever. That works mostly for things like Razor and Markdown processing though - it doesn't really work that well for stuff from the web because we have no way of knowing if anything has changed.

That said, you can obviously be a little smarter for this scenario than Statiq can be for a more generic feature, so some disk caching probably makes sense. There's a `ConcurrentCache<TKey, TValue>` class in `Statiq.Common` that might help: https://www.statiq.dev/api/statiq.common/concurrentcache_2/. It attempts to provide a slightly smarter concurrent dictionary you can use for storing cached data and (optionally) resetting in between executions.

One thing you probably do want to do is use `IFileSystem.CachePath` for the path where you're storing any cached files. That will ensure Statiq doesn't overwrite them or anything when it shouldn't and stay consistent with other cached information. The convention would probably be to create a subfolder under the `CachePath` directory for your own cached files. There are also some `IReadOnlyFileSystem` extensions for working with the cache path that can help resolve full file paths to the cache directory at runtime.

Here's a good example of some custom caching in action for the Razor module: https://github.com/statiqdev/Statiq.Framework/blob/1a8bd58e6f1a4e63f0cae2870db78126bc511928/src/extensions/Statiq.Razor/RazorService.cs#L56

> I'm also running into issues with the ReadWeb module from Statiq Framework that is spawning a task for each image

Yeah, that's probably an unfortunate design. It currently uses `ParallelSelectAsync` which is essentially a call to `Task.WhenAll()`, so while the task manager does have an upper task limit and some queuing built in, it's probably nowhere near reasonable for throttling web requests.

I'm getting a little bit of deja vu because I feel like I've tackled this problem a few times already. One approach off the top of my head is at: https://github.com/daveaglick/discoverdotnet/blob/master/FoundationManager.cs - that queues up web requests using a semaphore.

Anything inbox that does a better job of batching/queuing web requests would be a great addition - and I trust you, so I wouldn't need to review it very closely which is an added bonus :)

issue.title: Use of Assembly.Location makes this incompatible with single file EXEs

labels.name: Out Of Scope
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issue.body:
For a project I am working on, I was interested in trying out the [single file EXE](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/deploying/single-file/overview?tabs=cli).  Unfortunately, due to the use of `Assembly.Location` [in at least one spot](https://github.com/daveaglick/Buildalyzer/blob/main/src/Buildalyzer/ProjectAnalyzer.cs#L255) (which is [incompatible with single file EXEs](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/deploying/single-file/overview?tabs=cli#api-incompatibility)) causes the application to hang indefinitely while attempting to build the project out of process.

The output of the [`ProcessRunner`](https://github.com/daveaglick/Buildalyzer/blob/main/src/Buildalyzer/ProjectAnalyzer.cs#L167) shows the logger switch causes the build to fail, and apparently never return:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38168572/190872350-f54c5241-5cf2-4ce8-965f-42eedd7159f5.png)

Of course, the workaround is to _not_ do a single file EXE, but the single file feature is quite nice.

issue.title: How to do a (fast) design-time build?

comment.body:
Buildalyzer works by calling MSBuild from the command line (the same way you can) while passing it a special logger that sends messages over a pipe back to Buildalyzer for analysis. Performing a "real" design-time build is a challenge - Visual Studio and other IDEs set _a lot_ of different MSBuild properties to make that work correctly, and the correct combinations aren't well documented (if at all).

For C# I was able to reverse-engineer the set of properties to use, which Buildalyzer does by setting environment variables before calling MSBuild. However, in F# the code was entirely donated by the community - I know very little about how the F# compiler works and interacts with MSBuild outside of the unit tests in Buildalyzer I use to verify it's at least returning results. My ability to debug Buildalyzer working against an F# project is very limited. If you happen to figure out the correct set of MSBuild properties to configure for a fast design-time build of an F# project, let me know and we can look at updating the MSBuild call with those. The first step would probably be seeing if you can get it to work from a raw MSBuild command-line (I.e. without Buildalyzer at all) by using the MSBuild CLI switch for setting properties - play around with that until you figure out the right super-set of properties, then we can integrate them.

issue.title: Fix Lunr Search Resource Paths
issue.body:
At present, setting the `SearchScriptPath` key does not change the script path as expected, but changes the index path. This patch fixes the `SearchScriptPath` to work as expected, as well as adding keys to set the path for the index and results file.

Note that as this changes the behaviour of the existing `SearchScriptPath` key, this should be considered a breaking change. However, dealing with this is simply a matter of changing `SearchScriptPath` to `SearchIndexPath` in any configuration.

This also addresses a "feature" in Azure Static Apps, where files ending in `.gz` are served with compression headers, causing browsers to automatically decompress the file before passing the result to javascript. This causes the search script to fail, as it is expecting compressed data.

pull_request.body:
At present, setting the `SearchScriptPath` key does not change the script path as expected, but changes the index path. This patch fixes the `SearchScriptPath` to work as expected, as well as adding keys to set the path for the index and results file.

Note that as this changes the behaviour of the existing `SearchScriptPath` key, this should be considered a breaking change. However, dealing with this is simply a matter of changing `SearchScriptPath` to `SearchIndexPath` in any configuration.

This also addresses a "feature" in Azure Static Apps, where files ending in `.gz` are served with compression headers, causing browsers to automatically decompress the file before passing the result to javascript. This causes the search script to fail, as it is expecting compressed data.

issue.title: Update dependencies, refactor styles and scripts, add some goodies
issue.body:
Since #15 and #16 are unfortunately out of date, here's an update to current versions.

**EDIT:** I kinda got carried away 😁 so here are more changes:

- Update styles and scripts from [upstream](https://github.com/StartBootstrap/startbootstrap-clean-blog) where they have undergone some serious refactoring.
- Refactor styles to better separate upstream styles from modifications and expand override possibilities (e.g. make customization of Bootstrap variables possible by just adding one input file in a site).
- Remove styles, scripts and dependencies that were only used by the contacts page.
- Refactor what little JavaScript remains to not use jQuery.
- Remove jQuery as neither Bootstrap 5 nor upstream code depends on it any more.
- Add better styling for blockquotes (see #22) ![blockquote](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/139223/197311285-d3cda467-8371-4684-9dc5-8e130abd4131.png)
- Add pluggable comment engines and Giscus support (see #24)
- Add an `IsArchive` boolean setting to archive pages (index, posts, tags) and use it to tell them apart from other pages instead of comparing page titles - this also fixes the unwanted presence of a comment section in posts/index.html
- Move the navbar's `<ul>` tag in `_navigation.cshtml`, leaving only the items in `_navbar.cshtml`
- Make the navbar's search field a proper navbar item, so that there's a correct margin between it and the last navbar link
- Add a `.editorconfig` file to the repository for better collaboration
- Remove unused images (i.e. the whole `img` folder)
- Remove redundant favicon link
- Remove unused sidebar styles
- Make the masthead gradient configurable

comment.body:
Whoah! This is some amazing work. I'll make every effort to take a closer look soon and get it merged. Thankfully I'm less worried about breakage and backwards compatibility in the themes than in the actual libraries - I figure themes are going to evolve naturally and folks can pick them up at whatever commit makes sense for them (or not backport at all if they're already up and running). So mainly I'll just be looking to make sure everything still builds and works correctly with the various edge cases I've seen over the years.

Stay tuned!

issue.title: Email Addresses in mailto links are incorrectly escaped
issue.body: When linking to an email address in markdown, link text is displayed correctly but the hyperlink has extra escaping on the `@` character, which breaks the email address. For example: `[test@examples.com](mailto:test@example.com)` becomes `test@example.com` I believe this is being caused by double-escaping somewhere, as `@` is the correct entity for the `@` character.

comment.body: There's a tricky dance that happens with escaping the `@` symbol and Razor parsing. Even though escaping `@` isn't necessary for plain old Markdown, it's so common to run Statiq documents through the Razor processor, that escaping them after Markdown rendering is the default behavior. If you're creating your own pipelines and want to turn off automatic `@` escaping entirely (which is only advisable when _not_ using Razor downstream of the Markdown module), you can call `EscapeAt(false)` on the `RenderMarkdown` module: ``` // ... new RenderMarkdown().EscapeAt(false); // ... ``` Otherwise there's really no way to tell when an `@` symbol in post-Markdown content is intended to be a Razor instruction or was from the Markdown output, so they all get escaped. If you want to disable this behavior for a specific `@` symbol as with a `mailto:` link, you can escape it with `\@`: ``` [test\@examples.com](mailto:test\@example.com) ``` That produces: ``` test@examples.com ``` Which obviously isn't _quite_ right because the `@` symbol in the `a` element is still escaped. That's because of the way the Markdown renderer sequences the generated link element output vs. the content rendering, and where the escaping happens. To get _exactly_ what you want, you can put the mail link HTML right in the Markdown document, with the `\@` escaping: ``` test\@example.com ``` Which produces the desired unescaped output: ``` test@example.com ``` Note that this all appears to be academic. The client should correctly interpret the HTML entities and convert them back to the correct characters: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1020407/206793890-d106ae24-69d9-49fb-82d5-581ecdd5a841.png) Is that not what you're seeing? I.e. in the rendered output does the `mailto:` link with `#64;` entities not work when clicked or display to the user incorrectly?

issue.title: Netlify deployment not deploying dot files/directories
issue.body:
As reported by @patriksvensson if you create a folder like `.well-known` it'll get generated and output as expected, but won't deploy to Netlify. Thanks to @nils-a for finding this Netlify thread that seems to explain and confirm the behavior: https://answers.netlify.com/t/netlify-deploy-api-removes-files-and-directories-beginning-with-a-period/37728

So the questions is how to fix it? We could automatically look for this pattern, move the files, and create redirect entries as suggested in https://github.com/netlify/cli/issues/11#issuecomment-401854074, but that seems _really_ hacky.

pull_request.title: Update dependencies, refactor styles and scripts, add some goodies
pull_request.body:
Since #15 and #16 are unfortunately out of date, here's an update to current versions.

**EDIT:** I kinda got carried away 😁 so here are more changes:

- Update styles and scripts from [upstream](https://github.com/StartBootstrap/startbootstrap-clean-blog) where they have undergone some serious refactoring.
- Refactor styles to better separate upstream styles from modifications and expand override possibilities (e.g. make customization of Bootstrap variables possible by just adding one input file in a site).
- Remove styles, scripts and dependencies that were only used by the contacts page.
- Refactor what little JavaScript remains to not use jQuery.
- Remove jQuery as neither Bootstrap 5 nor upstream code depends on it any more.
- Add better styling for blockquotes (see #22) ![blockquote](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/139223/197311285-d3cda467-8371-4684-9dc5-8e130abd4131.png)
- Add pluggable comment engines and Giscus support (see #24)
- Add an `IsPage` boolean setting for pages ("About" and the like). Pages should be put in a `pages` folder and are added to the navigation bar by default.
- Set `Order` to 98 for Posts and 99 for Tags, thus establishing a clear rule for navbar links: pages with an `Order` of at least 100 will be linked after archives.
- Rename `_post-footer` partial to `_post-after-content` as it is not actually included in the footer.
- Add a `_page-after-content` partial for consistency with `_post-after-content`.
- Add a `_common-after-content` partial for _all_ pages, included just after `_post-after-content` in posts and just after `_page-after-content` in pages.
- Move the navbar's `<ul>` tag in `_navigation.cshtml`, leaving only the items in `_navbar.cshtml`
- Make the navbar's search field a proper navbar item, so that there's a correct margin between it and the last navbar link.
- Add a `.editorconfig` file to the repository for better collaboration.
- Remove unused images (i.e. the whole `img` folder).
- Remove redundant favicon link.
- Remove unused sidebar styles.
- Make the masthead gradient configurable.
- Add support for an `ImageAttribution` setting. If it is present in any page, a nice semi-transparent badge is created in the lower-right corner of the masthead, with the value of `ImageAttribution` inserted as raw HTML. Makes displaying proper attribution for images very easy, for example when using photos from [Unsplash](https://unsplash.com).
- Make the copyright notice fully customizable, so for example proper CC licensing can be applied without having to override the whole footer.
- Add support for a `SiteDescription` global setting to set the home page subtitle.

- Remove unused images (i.e. the whole `img` folder).
- Remove redundant favicon link.
- Remove unused sidebar styles.
- Make the masthead gradient configurable.
- Add support for an `ImageAttribution` setting. If it is present in any page, a nice semi-transparent badge is created in the lower-right corner of the masthead, with the value of `ImageAttribution` inserted as raw HTML. Makes displaying proper attribution for images very easy, for example when using photos from [Unsplash](https://unsplash.com).
- Make the copyright notice fully customizable, so for example proper CC licensing can be applied without having to override the whole footer.
- Add support for a `SiteDescription` global setting to set the home page subtitle.

issue.title: Update dependencies, refactor styles and scripts, add some goodies
issue.body:
Since #15 and #16 are unfortunately out of date, here's an update to current versions.

**EDIT:** I kinda got carried away 😁 so here are more changes:

- Update styles and scripts from [upstream](https://github.com/StartBootstrap/startbootstrap-clean-blog) where they have undergone some serious refactoring.
- Refactor styles to better separate upstream styles from modifications and expand override possibilities (e.g. make customization of Bootstrap variables possible by just adding one input file in a site).
- Remove styles, scripts and dependencies that were only used by the contacts page.
- Refactor what little JavaScript remains to not use jQuery.
- Remove jQuery as neither Bootstrap 5 nor upstream code depends on it any more.
- Add better styling for blockquotes (see #22) ![blockquote](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/139223/197311285-d3cda467-8371-4684-9dc5-8e130abd4131.png)
- Add pluggable comment engines and Giscus support (see #24)
- Add an `IsPage` boolean setting for pages ("About" and the like). Pages should be put in a `pages` folder and are added to the navigation bar by default.
- Set `Order` to 98 for Posts and 99 for Tags, thus establishing a clear rule for navbar links: pages with an `Order` of at least 100 will be linked after archives.
- Rename `_post-footer` partial to `_post-after-content` as it is not actually included in the footer.
- Add a `_page-after-content` partial for consistency with `_post-after-content`.
- Add a `_common-after-content` partial for _all_ pages, included just after `_post-after-content` in posts and just after `_page-after-content` in pages.
- Move the navbar's `<ul>` tag in `_navigation.cshtml`, leaving only the items in `_navbar.cshtml`
- Make the navbar's search field a proper navbar item, so that there's a correct margin between it and the last navbar link.
- Add a `.editorconfig` file to the repository for better collaboration.
- Remove unused images (i.e. the whole `img` folder).
- Remove redundant favicon link.
- Remove unused sidebar styles.
- Make the masthead gradient configurable.
- Add support for an `ImageAttribution` setting. If it is present in any page, a nice semi-transparent badge is created in the lower-right corner of the masthead, with the value of `ImageAttribution` inserted as raw HTML. Makes displaying proper attribution for images very easy, for example when using photos from [Unsplash](https://unsplash.com).
- Make the copyright notice fully customizable, so for example proper CC licensing can be applied without having to override the whole footer.
- Add support for a `SiteDescription` global setting to set the home page subtitle.

---

Oh, by the way - closes #25

comment.body:
I don't want to drag this out any longer than we need to since it's already been on the shelf for a while. @atiq-cs I really appreciate your willingness to do a full review! Is there a middle ground though where you'd be able to just run through a generation with the new theme and see if anything sticks out? I don't know that we have to verify every change, just make sure it's not going to blow up on new users. If we've passed that minimum bar I'm okay merging it in - we can always iterate and/or fix things as they come later.

Thanks both!

comment.body:
Go team! Thanks for the input everyone, glad I surfaced this one to the community.

> In that case I think a separate pr is cleaner.

I agree, and in general I try to stick to the lowest possible target to allow the largest number of consumers. I've been on the consumption end where I'm unable to update my own targeting so I appreciate when projects don't retarget just for retargeting sake.

@colombod let's do this:
- Microsoft.CodeAnalysis.CSharp.Workspaces 4.4.0 only has a dependency on .NET Core 3.1, so let's make this PR just for that update. Then I can get a release out with the updated workspaces library.

That should let Stryker (one of our most active contributors) continue to consume without issue while bumping us to a supported platform. By separating the PRs and releases we can also let anyone who needs to stay on .NET Core 3.1 get the workspaces update and then hang out on that release.

Sound good?

issue.body:
### Description

...
Project and references (235 source files) parsed in 3443ms

Started Fable compilation...

Adding `global.json` with sdk version set to `6.0.403` fixes the problem.

issue.title: Improve image handling
issue.body:
### Motivation

* Prevent repeatedly downloading images in preview mode
* Workaround for #39 

### Checklist

- [X] Code follows coding conventions held in this repo
- [ ] Automated tests have been added
- [ ] Tests are passing
- [ ] Docs have been updated (if applicable)
- [ ] Temporary settings (e.g. variables used during development and testing) have been reverted to defaults

### How to test

If manual testing is required, what are the steps?

comment.body:
I'm here! Well...sort of. You probably know as well as anyone how flaky my available time has been this year.

In any case, I did get a chance to take a look at the stuff here.

> I noticed Statiq is caching some files already, is there a mechanism in Statiq I can hook into as well?

There isn't really a generic file-based caching mechanism. That said, Statiq does try to track the files it writes, and if the input to a module is the same as a previous run, and the file on disk hasn't changed, it can be a little clever. That works mostly for things like Razor and Markdown processing though - it doesn't really work that well for stuff from the web because we have no way of knowing if anything has changed.

That said, you can obviously be a little smarter for this scenario than Statiq can be for a more generic feature, so some disk caching probably makes sense. There's a `ConcurrentCache<TKey, TValue>` class in `Statiq.Common` that might help: https://www.statiq.dev/api/statiq.common/concurrentcache_2/. It attempts to provide a slightly smarter concurrent dictionary you can use for storing cached data and (optionally) resetting in between executions.

One thing you probably do want to do is use `IFileSystem.CachePath` for the path where you're storing any cached files. That will ensure Statiq doesn't overwrite them or anything when it shouldn't and stay consistent with other cached information. The convention would probably be to create a subfolder under the `CachePath` directory for your own cached files. There are also some `IReadOnlyFileSystem` extensions for working with the cache path that can help resolve full file paths to the cache directory at runtime.

Here's a good example of some custom caching in action for the Razor module: https://github.com/statiqdev/Statiq.Framework/blob/1a8bd58e6f1a4e63f0cae2870db78126bc511928/src/extensions/Statiq.Razor/RazorService.cs#L56

> I'm also running into issues with the ReadWeb module from Statiq Framework that is spawning a task for each image

Yeah, that's probably an unfortunate design. It currently uses `ParallelSelectAsync` which is essentially a call to `Task.WhenAll()`, so while the task manager does have an upper task limit and some queuing built in, it's probably nowhere near reasonable for throttling web requests.

I'm getting a little bit of deja vu because I feel like I've tackled this problem a few times already. One approach off the top of my head is at: https://github.com/daveaglick/discoverdotnet/blob/master/FoundationManager.cs - that queues up web requests using a semaphore.

Anything inbox that does a better job of batching/queuing web requests would be a great addition - and I trust you, so I wouldn't need to review it very closely which is an added bonus :)

issue.body:
For a project I am working on, I was interested in trying out the [single file EXE](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/deploying/single-file/overview?tabs=cli).  Unfortunately, due to the use of `Assembly.Location` [in at least one spot](https://github.com/daveaglick/Buildalyzer/blob/main/src/Buildalyzer/ProjectAnalyzer.cs#L255) (which is [incompatible with single file EXEs](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/deploying/single-file/overview?tabs=cli#api-incompatibility)) causes the application to hang indefinitely while attempting to build the project out of process.

The output of the [`ProcessRunner`](https://github.com/daveaglick/Buildalyzer/blob/main/src/Buildalyzer/ProjectAnalyzer.cs#L167) shows the logger switch causes the build to fail, and apparently never return:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38168572/190872350-f54c5241-5cf2-4ce8-965f-42eedd7159f5.png)

Of course, the workaround is to _not_ do a single file EXE, but the single file feature is quite nice.

issue.title: How to do a (fast) design-time build?

comment.body:
Buildalyzer works by calling MSBuild from the command line (the same way you can) while passing it a special logger that sends messages over a pipe back to Buildalyzer for analysis. Performing a "real" design-time build is a challenge - Visual Studio and other IDEs set _a lot_ of different MSBuild properties to make that work correctly, and the correct combinations aren't well documented (if at all).

For C# I was able to reverse-engineer the set of properties to use, which Buildalyzer does by setting environment variables before calling MSBuild. However, in F# the code was entirely donated by the community - I know very little about how the F# compiler works and interacts with MSBuild outside of the unit tests in Buildalyzer I use to verify it's at least returning results. My ability to debug Buildalyzer working against an F# project is very limited. If you happen to figure out the correct set of MSBuild properties to configure for a fast design-time build of an F# project, let me know and we can look at updating the MSBuild call with those. The first step would probably be seeing if you can get it to work from a raw MSBuild command-line (I.e. without Buildalyzer at all) by using the MSBuild CLI switch for setting properties - play around with that until you figure out the right super-set of properties, then we can integrate them.

issue.title: Source files are ignored by generator
issue.body:
Not sure what is going on here. I've tried a bunch of different configurations and can't get anything to work.

I followed the steps [here](https://www.statiq.dev/docs).

Then I clone [my project](https://github.com/rhys-vdw/peachy-tween/tree/a96b448ab6947e138ef121e15da161b19223d7fb) into the `src` folder.

```
git clone git@github.com:rhys-vdw/peachy-tween.git src
```

Now, if I run the project I get errors because it's trying to include the source folder, so I edit my csproj to look like this:

```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>net6.0</TargetFramework>
    <ImplicitUsings>enable</ImplicitUsings>
    <Nullable>enable</Nullable>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <!-- added these -->
    <Content Remove="src\**" />
    <Compile Remove="src\**" />
    <EmbeddedResource Remove="src\**" />
    <None Remove="src\**" />
    <!-- end-->
    <PackageReference Include="Statiq.Docs" Version="1.0.0-beta.5" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```

And when I run the output folder contains only `sitemap.xml`

```
[INFO] -> Code/Input » Starting Code Input phase execution... (0 input document(s), 1 module(s))
```

issue.title: Fix Lunr Search Resource Paths
issue.body:
At present, setting the `SearchScriptPath` key does not change the script path as expected, but changes the index path. This patch fixes the `SearchScriptPath` to work as expected, as well as adding keys to set the path for the index and results file.

Note that as this changes the behaviour of the existing `SearchScriptPath` key, this should be considered a breaking change. However, dealing with this is simply a matter of changing `SearchScriptPath` to `SearchIndexPath` in any configuration.

This also addresses a "feature" in Azure Static Apps, where files ending in `.gz` are served with compression headers, causing browsers to automatically decompress the file before passing the result to javascript. This causes the search script to fail, as it is expecting compressed data.

issue.body:
At present, setting the `SearchScriptPath` key does not change the script path as expected, but changes the index path. This patch fixes the `SearchScriptPath` to work as expected, as well as adding keys to set the path for the index and results file.

Note that as this changes the behaviour of the existing `SearchScriptPath` key, this should be considered a breaking change. However, dealing with this is simply a matter of changing `SearchScriptPath` to `SearchIndexPath` in any configuration.

issue.title: Update dependencies, refactor styles and scripts, add some goodies
issue.body:
Since #15 and #16 are unfortunately out of date, here's an update to current versions.

**EDIT:** I kinda got carried away 😁 so here are more changes:

- Update styles and scripts from [upstream](https://github.com/StartBootstrap/startbootstrap-clean-blog) where they have undergone some serious refactoring.
- Refactor styles to better separate upstream styles from modifications and expand override possibilities (e.g. make customization of Bootstrap variables possible by just adding one input file in a site).
- Remove styles, scripts and dependencies that were only used by the contacts page.
- Refactor what little JavaScript remains to not use jQuery.
- Remove jQuery as neither Bootstrap 5 nor upstream code depends on it any more.
- Add better styling for blockquotes (see #22) ![blockquote](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/139223/197311285-d3cda467-8371-4684-9dc5-8e130abd4131.png)
- Add pluggable comment engines and Giscus support (see #24)
- Add an `IsArchive` boolean setting to archive pages (index, posts, tags) and use it to tell them apart from other pages instead of comparing page titles - this also fixes the unwanted presence of a comment section in posts/index.html
- Move the navbar's `<ul>` tag in `_navigation.cshtml`, leaving only the items in `_navbar.cshtml`
- Make the navbar's search field a proper navbar item, so that there's a correct margin between it and the last navbar link
- Add a `.editorconfig` file to the repository for better collaboration
- Remove unused images (i.e. the whole `img` folder)
- Remove redundant favicon link
- Remove unused sidebar styles
- Make the masthead gradient configurable

comment.body:
Whoah! This is some amazing work. I'll make every effort to take a closer look soon and get it merged. Thankfully I'm less worried about breakage and backwards compatibility in the themes than in the actual libraries - I figure themes are going to evolve naturally and folks can pick them up at whatever commit makes sense for them (or not backport at all if they're already up and running). So mainly I'll just be looking to make sure everything still builds and works correctly with the various edge cases I've seen over the years.

Stay tuned!

review.body: Everything here looks fine to me, and I'm running Statiq on .NET 7 elsewhere so there shouldn't be any compatibility issues. That said I've heard the Foundation is completely dropping Statiq soon (though no one has actually approached me or otherwise looped me in), so I wouldn't put too much effort into ongoing upkeep like this.
